page.article: Kellogg’s Profit Falls; Sara Lee Cuts Sales ForecastPublished: November 3, 2011Kellogg said on Thursday that it was spending an additional $70 million in the second half of 2011 to improve its manufacturing, a move that led to a weaker-than-expected third-quarter profit.Separately, Sara Lee cut its full-year sales forecast when it reported its third-quarter earnings results. Kellogg, the cereal maker, whose brands include Corn Flakes and Rice Krispies, also said its 2012 earnings would be below its long-term forecasts. John A. Bryant, who has been Kellogg’s chief executive for less than a year, said the company “cut deeper than it should have” and was now reversing course to add people back into factories. He said the company was also improving employee training and interaction with suppliers. “We’re making the investments we need to make to ensure that our supply chain is performing at the level we need it to perform at in the future,” said Mr. Bryant, who was chief operating officer when many of the cuts were made. “We’d all rather do that without having to spend $70 million,” he said, adding, “but I think it was absolutely the right thing to do.” In June, regulators found listeria at a Kellogg plant in Georgia that produced Keebler and Famous Amos cookies, and warned the company about “significant violations” of good manufacturing practice regulations. That followed a recall of millions of boxes of cereal in 2010 because of an unusual smell, and a recall of some Keebler cookies and Special K protein bars in 2009. Kellogg’s net income was $290 million, or 80 cents a share, in the third quarter, down from $338 million, or 90 cents a share, a year earlier. The results were also hurt by reinstating a companywide bonus program. Net sales rose 5 percent, to $3.31 billion. Analysts on average had expected earnings of 89 cents a share on sales of $3.41 billion, according to Thomson Reuters. Kellogg expects full-year earnings of $3.27 to $3.33 a share, excluding currency fluctuations, or $3.35 to $3.41, including an estimated 8-cent-a-share benefit from foreign exchange. That is lower than the forecast implied by its previous target and analysts’ estimate of $3.48 a share. The company stood by its net sales growth goal of 4 to 5 percent. For 2012, Kellogg also expects net sales growth of 4 to 5 percent, which is above its long-term annual targets, as it expects benefits from new products and price increases. Kellogg shares fell 7.6 percent, to $49.91, on Thursday. Meanwhile, Sara Lee stood by its full-year earnings forecast, saying it still expected adjusted earnings of 89 to 95 cents a share in fiscal 2012, even though the weakening euro reduced its expected foreign exchange benefit and the company announced a plan to sell its North American food service coffee business. Those issues led the company to cut its full-year sales forecast to $7.9 billion to $8.15 billion, from a previous forecast of $8.5 billion to $8.75 billion. For the first quarter of fiscal 2012, which ended on Oct. 1, Sara Lee reported a net loss of $217 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier profit of $192 million, or 29 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, Sara Lee reported a profit of 18 cents a share, topping analysts’ average expectation by a penny, according to Thomson Reuters. Sales rose to $1.94 billion from $1.73 billion a year earlier. Analysts on average were expecting sales of $1.98 billion. Sara Lee, based in a suburb of Chicago, is planning to split into two companies — one focused on North American meat brands including Jimmy Dean sausages and Ball Park frankfurters, and the other on international coffee and teas, with brands like Douwe Egberts and Pickwick. Sara Lee shares were up $1.09, or 6 percent, at $18.70.Kellogg said on Thursday that it was spending an additional $70 million in the second half of 2011 to improve its manufacturing, a move that led to a weaker-than-expected third-quarter profit.

Ralcorp to Buy a Sara Lee Unit for $545 MillionAugust 9, 2011, 7:57 amSara Lee and Ralcorp are both food companies that have been busy trying to remake themselves this year. On Tuesday, they reached a deal toward that mutual end. Sara Lee has agreed to sell its North American private-brand refrigerated dough business to Ralcorp for $545 million. The sale comes as Sara Lee is preparing to split into two separate food and beverage companies. The sale, said Marcel Smits, the company’s chief executive, “will better enable our North American business to focus on its branded meats and frozen desserts products and establish a platform for a strong and independent future.” Ralcorp, meanwhile, is spinning off its Post Foods cereal business. The refrigerated dough acquisition will bolster its private brand business, while the proceeds from the Post Foods split will help pay back the short-term debt being used to finance the acquisition. It employs about 700 and has manufacturing plants in Forest Park, Ga., and Carrollton, Tex.

Sara Lee Posts $153 Million ProfitPublished: May 5, 2011The Sara Lee Corporation posted a quarterly profit on Thursday, reversing a loss a year ago, but cut its full-year outlook because of rising commodity costs and said it might sell two units.The company, which has sold several business lines and is splitting in two, says it is considering selling its international bakery and North American refrigerated dough businesses. Sara Lee reported net income of $153 million, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter ended April 2, the third quarter of its fiscal year. That compared with a loss of $336 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding one-time items, the company earned 24 cents a share, up from 22 cents a share a year ago but short of the 25 cents expected by analysts surveyed by FactSet. Revenue in the period rose 7 percent, to $2.22 billion from $2.07 billion, helped by higher prices among other factors. But investors were receptive to Sara Lee’s commitment to narrowing its business and shedding lower-performing operations, and its stock rose 14 cents to close at $19.28 a share on Thursday. Sara Lee, which is based in Downers Grove, Ill., has raised prices and cut costs to offset higher costs for meat, coffee and other commodities. But Sara Lee leaders said prices might now be high enough to make less expensive store brands more attractive to consumers, further hurting profits. The company now expects to earn 79 to 83 cents a share on an adjusted basis, down from its previous forecast of 85 to 89 cents a share and below the 86 cents analysts expected.The Sara Lee Corporation posted a quarterly profit on Thursday, reversing a loss a year ago, but cut its full-year outlook because of rising commodity costs and said it might sell two units.

Sara Lee Confirms Plan to SplitJanuary 28, 2011, 8:29 amSeth Perlman/Associated Pres Sara Lee‘s board announced Friday the company will split its food and beverage businesses into two separate companies, a deal they expect to close by 2012. The announcement comes after the company rejected at least two preliminary takeover approaches. The food business, which includes meat products like Jimmy Dean and Ball Park, will be spun off into a new public company that will keep the Sara Lee brand name. It had revenue of $4.1 billion last year Article Tools E-mail This Print Recommend Share Close Tumblr Digg Linkedin Reddit Permalink Related Links The press release DealBook: Sara Lee Weighs Breakup The as yet unnamed beverage company will carry a number of coffee brands, like Douwe Egberts, Senseo and Pickwick. Beverages generated revenue $4.6 billion last year. Sara Lee also announced that Marcel Smits, 49, who has been serving as interim chief executive since Brenda C. Barnes resigned, will get the job on a permanent basis. Ms. Barnes resigned as chief executive and chairman in August, three months after suffering a stroke. Jan Bennink, 54, will become chairman, replacing Jim Crown, who will continue to serve on the board. The board also said that C.J. Fraleigh, 47, who serves as Sara Lee’s chief executive for North America, will be named chief executive of the food spinoff. The board also announced plans to pay a $3 dollar per share special dividend to common stock shareholders following the sale of its North American Bakery unit, which the company announced in November. The dividend is to be paid in 2012, before the expected spinoff of the company’s food division. “We have carefully considered various strategic alternatives, including unsolicited indications of interest in the company. We believe that the spinoff, plus the one-time special dividend, offers the greatest potential for delivering long-term shareholder value,” James Crown, Sara Lee’s chairman, said in a statement. “These two pure-play companies will have their own distinct growth strategies within their respective core markets that will attract a more focused shareholder base.” Both a private equity consortium led by Apollo Global Management and JBS, a large Brazilian meat producer, have made separate, preliminary takeover approaches for Sara Lee. But on Thursday, Sara Lee directors determined that the prices being mentioned were not high enough, said people briefed on the matter who spoke only on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly. The split is the latest realignment by an American corporate giant. Both ITT and Fortune Brands plan to break up into three companies, while the Marathon Oil Corporation wants to spin off its refining and marketing business. Sara Lee, based in Illiinois, has been shrinking over the last decade, selling off a wide range of businesses like Coach handbags and and underwear business that included Hanes. More recently the company sold its North American bakery business to Grupo Bimbo of Mexico for $959 million and its global body care and European detergents business in 2009 to Unilever for 1.3 billion euros, or $1.8 billion. But it began considering a sale or breakup after Ms. Barnes resigned. While Sara Lee had appointed an interim chief executive, the company had slowed its search for a permanent replacement for Ms. Barnes while weighing options for its future.

Sara Lee Said Weighing a Breakup, Not a TakeoverPublished: January 28, 20117:13 p.m. | Updated The board of Sara Lee has rejected takeover overtures from two potential buyers and is likely to pursue a breakup of the company into separate meat and coffee businesses, people briefed on the matter said Thursday. Such a split would be the latest realignment by an American corporate giant. Both ITT and Fortune Brands plan to break up into three companies, while the Marathon Oil Corporationwants to spin off its refining and marketing business. But the move would frustrate those hoping for a bidding war for Sara Lee, which has a market value of $11.3 billion. Both a private equity consortium led by Apollo Global Management and JBS, a large Brazilian meat producer, have made separate, preliminary takeover approaches for Sara Lee. But on Thursday, Sara Lee directors determined that the prices being mentioned were not high enough, the people briefed on the matter, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said. These people, however, cautioned that the situation remained fluid, adding that Sara Lee might still entertain takeover offers even after it began the process of splitting itself up. A formal announcement may come in the next few days, one of these people said. A Sara Lee spokesman declined to comment. Shares of Sara Lee fell 4.75 percent on Thursday, to $17.64, after TheDeal.com reported on the board's decision. Sara Lee has previously rejected takeover approaches. The company rebuffed several informal merger proposals last fall, including those by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and JBS, arguing that they were not high enough, people briefed on the matter have previously said. JBS, which already owns beef and pork producers in the United States, has been pursuing Sara Lee to cap a big expansion in North America. JBS has indicated to Sara Lee that if it acquired the American company, it would sell its coffee business to the Blackstone Group, these people said. But JBS has had trouble coming up with the financing to push its bid past $20 a share, these people said, and, by Thursday, had stopped trying to line up the necessary loans. The Apollo-led group, which also includes TPG Capital and Bain Capital, has not submitted a new bid after making a preliminary offer last week that came in under $20, these people said. Sara Lee had suggested to the private equity consortium that it would need to raise its offer to be taken seriously. Sara Lee had told both bidders that it would be willing to pursue a breakup if it received no satisfactory bids by the time its board met on Wednesday and Thursday. That move could prove more attractive than a sale because it could spare shareholders from a big tax bill, though it remains a complicated transaction. Sara Lee has already shed several units in recent years. It sold its North American bakery business last year to Grupo Bimbo of Mexico for $959 million and its global body care and European detergents business in 2009 to Unilever for 1.3 billion euros, or $1.8 billion. But it began considering a sale or breakup after Brenda C. Barnes resigned as chairwoman and chief executive last August, three months after suffering a stroke. While Sara Lee had appointed an interim chief executive, the company had slowed its search for a permanent replacement for Ms. Barnes while weighing options for its future. Bidders for Sara Lee Face ChallengesJanuary 26, 2011, 12:24 pmAt least one of the potential bidders for Sara Lee, JBS of Brazil, is having difficulty raising the financing necessary for its offer, making a bid increasingly less likely, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday. The other potential suitor, a consortium led by Apollo Global Management, is also weighing whether to raise its preliminary bid for Sara Lee after it submitted an offer late last week. Sara Lee has told both bidders that it would be willing to pursue a breakup of itself if it receives no satisfactory bids by the time its board meets on Wednesday and Thursday, said these people, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly on the matter. But a final decision from the company could still be days away, and either bidder could still come back with a higher offer. JBS has indicated to Sara Lee that if it acquired the American company, it would sell its coffee business to the Blackstone Group, these people said. But JBS has had trouble coming up with the financing to push its bid past $20 a share, these people said. JBS had been seeking to buy Sara Lee to cap off a series of acquisitions to expand internationally, a string of deals that included buying a majority stake in Pilgrim’s Pride, the big American poultry producer, in 2009. But Sara Lee had rejected a previous JBS approach last fall, concerned that the combined companies would bear too much debt. Selling off the coffee business to Blackstone was meant in part to alleviate those worries. The Apollo-led group’s offer valued Sara Lee at a range of less than $20 a share, these people said. It is unclear whether the consortium, which also includes TPG Capital and Bain Capital, would also seek to break up the company. A Sara Lee spokesman declined to comment. One concern for the Sara Lee board is how to grapple with tax issues surrounding a potential sale of the company’s coffee business. Before receiving the preliminary offers from JBS and the Apollo group, Sara Lee’s directors had been leaning toward spinning off the beverage unit in a tax-free transaction, hoping to spare shareholders from being stuck with a big bill, these people said. But the company’s board may favor a takeover if the price is high enough to compensate for the tax issues, these people said.

Sara Lee Favors Split After Rebuffing JBSJanuary 6, 2011, 4:51 pmStephen Yang/Bloomberg News Sara Lee is leaning toward splitting itself into its meats and coffee businesses after rejecting a takeover bid by JBS of Brazil, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday. During months of on-again and off-again deal discussions, Sara Lee was not convinced that JBS, a major meat processor, could secure adequate financing for a takeover, these people said. Because the two are of similar size, any merger would likely saddle the combined company with significant debt. With no other bidders on the horizon — preliminary offers by leveraged buyout firms including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts were rejected this fall — Sara Lee is instead looking to split its main businesses. A decision could be made by the end of this month, said one of these people, who requested anonymity because they were not authorized to talk publicly about the split. Article Tools E-mail This Print Recommend Share Close Tumblr Digg Linkedin Reddit Permalink The exact structure has not yet been decided, given the complexity of such a breakup. A split could leave the meats business — which owns brands like Jimmy Dean and Hillshire Farms — financially weakened, since much of Sara Lee’s free cash flow arises from the beverage unit, according to Eric Serotta, an analyst for Wells Fargo Securities. Still, splitting Sara Lee into its meat and coffee units could make the sale of each easier for a suitor like JBS, these people said. Other potential buyers could include Smithfield, Tyson and Hormel, Mr. Serotta said. Trading in Sara Lee shares ended flat on Thursday at $17.46, giving the company a market value of about $11.2 billion. News of Sara Lee’s plans were first reported by The Wall Street Journal online. Sara Lee, based in Downers Grove, Ill., has been shedding assets in recent years to focus on faster-growing meat and beverage businesses. In late December, Sara Lee announced the sale of its White King and Janola cleaning brands to Symex Holdings for $50 million. Unilever closed on its purchase of Sara Lee’s body care business this month for $2.5 billion. And in November, Sara Lee sold its North American bakery operations to Mexico’s Grupo Bimbo for $959 million. One of the drivers for Sara Lee’s efforts to sell or split itself is the absence of a permanent chief executive since Brenda C. Barnes departed last August after suffering a stroke. Marcel Smits, who had been chief financial officer at the time of Ms. Barnes’s stroke, is filling in as interim chief executive. But that search has been slowed as the company decides whether to sell itself or more of its units, people briefed on the matter said.

Sara Lee to Sell Bakery Unit to Grupo BimboPublished: November 9, 2010The Sara Lee Corporation said on Tuesday that it would sell its North American bakery business to Grupo Bimbo of Mexico for $925 million, the latest move to shrink what was once a sprawling company with a product lineup including hot dogs and underwear.After the sale, in which Bimbo will also assume $34 million in debt, Sara Lee will focus on meats and coffee, with brands like Hillshire Farm lunch meat and Senseo coffee pods. The North American bakery unit generated $2.13 billion in sales in the fiscal year that ended Oct. 2, out of $10.79 billion for the entire company. “It was not a make-it-or-break-it piece for Sara Lee,” said Timothy Ramey, an analyst at D. A. Davidson. He said that the company might look more attractive without that low-margin business, which has been pressured by higher wheat costs and discounts on supermarket store shelves. Because of the sale of the bakery business, Sara Lee said it planned to accelerate its share buyback plans. It expects to complete the repurchase of $2.5 billion to $3 billion in stock by July 2012. For Bimbo, the acquisition is part of its push to become one of the largest players in North American bakeries. Nespresso and Rivals Vie for Dominance in Coffee WarPublished: August 20, 2010PARIS — George Clooney and John Malkovich aren’t the only coffee lovers fighting over a Nespresso these days.A coffee war has broken out in Europe pitting the Swiss food giant Nestlé against the struggling American food group Sara Lee as well as a former Nestlé executive. They are at odds over the worldwide monopoly Nespresso has long held on the lucrative espresso pods that fit its coffee-making machines. Helping propel its popularity in Europe is a sleekly wry English-language ad campaign featuring Mr. Clooney and Mr. Malkovich. With billions at stake, Nespresso has sued its rivals, accusing them of making cheaper copycat pods that violate the intellectual property it created in developing a system to make a convenient homemade cup of espresso that it claims can best a barista. The first court test could begin next month here, where Nespresso’s competitors recently put their pods on grocery store shelves in hopes of establishing a beachhead to make inroads throughout Europe and into the United States. “Nestlé has spent millions of dollars on innovation and research in Nespresso over many years,” said Richard Girardot, chief executive of Nestlé Nespresso. “So when someone comes along with a pure copy of the product, we have to protect ourselves.” But Nespresso’s rivals say that Nestlé is trying to lock them out of one of the fastest-growing segments of the coffee market: pods now account for 20 to 40 percent of the value of ground coffee sales in the $17 billion European coffee market, according to Euromonitor International. “What they’re doing is similar to Hewlett-Packard or Epson trying to forbid generic cartridges,” said Jean-Paul Gaillard, who ran Nespresso for a decade but who now is being sued by Nestlé for devising a biodegradable version of its capsule. “They are trying to stop copies — but our product is not a copy,” he said. Competitors have emerged to other single-serve coffee products, but Nestlé is the first to take legal action to try to ward generics away from the gold mine of coffee by the pod. “The real margins now are in capsulized coffee,” Mr. Gaillard said, “where you basically sell five grams of coffee for five times the price of what you’d get from regular roasted ground.” Sales have leapt 30 percent a year, on average, over the last decade, ever since Nespresso underwent an aggressive makeover that transformed it from a humdrum office coffee product to a must-have item among chic urbanites. Through star-studded advertising in Europe and Asia and a growing network of clubby boutiques now numbering 200, it lures upscale customers, whether in New York, Paris or Shanghai. Since 2000, when Nespresso started to break even, the company has sold more than 20 billion capsules through its boutiques and Web site at about 43 to 62 cents apiece. The price of its machines start around $190 and soar beyond $2,500. Given similar projections for future growth, others started trying to angle in. Nestlé has not made that easy: it owns the patents — 1,700 of them — on its personal espresso system, which Mr. Malkovich, playing God in Nespresso’s most recent European ads, trades for Mr. Clooney’s soul. Many of the patents are set to expire in 2012, and Nestlé has been working on other ways to prevent competitors from hacking a system that uses unique water dynamics to pump an espresso kissed with foam out of a hermetically sealed aluminum capsule. Sara Lee, which has been trying since 2005 to engineer a recovery, recently broke through. In mid-July, it put its own plastic perforated version of the capsule, the L’Or, in French supermarkets, at a price of 37 cents. So far, it has sold 30 million capsules, a spokesman said. “Coffee is Sara Lee’s No. 1 business; it accounts for well over 50 percent of their earnings,” said Tim Ramey, an analyst at D. A. Davidson & Company in Portland, Ore. “The single-serve coffee business is the piece that’s growing fast, so it’s important for them.” Sara Lee has its own low-cost version of a personal espresso machine, the Senseo, whose pods alone had sales of $555 million in the fiscal year that ended June 30. Senseo is a top seller in the American market and a rival to other single-serve coffees in the United States, like Green Mountain. If Sara Lee is confident, so is Mr. Gaillard, who started the Ethical Coffee Company three years ago to grab a piece of a market he knows inside out. He takes credit for dreaming up the way to make Nespresso a breakthrough product when he was the top executive there from 1988 to 1997, a claim that elicits long moments of silence from current executives. “I wanted to create the Chanel of coffee, and decided to make Nespresso chic and bobo,” he said. “The idea was to keep it to the level of people who have a doorman.”

Sara Lee Swings to a ProfitPublished: August 12, 2010The Sara Lee Corporation returned to profitability in its fourth quarter, but investors were wary of the company’s future in the face of rising commodity prices. Barnes, who stepped down this week to focus on her health after a stroke. Sara Lee, based in Downers Grove, Ill., has been trimming costs and product lines for several years to focus on its core food and beverage businesses. Sara Lee said lower prices on some items and higher marketing costs dragged on its results, but it made important gains like increasing market share for certain units and selling off noncore lines like body care. Revenue rose in North American retail and international beverages, Sara Lee’s biggest units. The increase was less pronounced in sales to businesses like hotels because of weak demand. And Sara Lee’s international bakery business also struggled from competition by store brands and weak sales in Spain. Down Economic Times Elicit Upbeat CampaignsPublished: March 9, 2009SAY goodbye to the dutiful Quaker Man who declared of his namesake oatmeal, “Nothing is better for thee than me.” He and the Quaker Oats division of PepsiCo are clambering aboard a fast-moving marketing bandwagon by offering upbeat exhortations during these tough economic times. Skip to next paragraph Enlarge This Image One ad shows a man flying to work with jets on his back powered by two packages of Old Fashioned Quaker Oats. Add to Portfolio PepsiCo Inc Sara Lee Corp Bank of America Corp Go to your Portfolio » “Go humans go” is the theme of a major campaign getting under way for Quaker Oats. The theme acts as an umbrella under which all the division’s oat-based products are being peddled; as an announcer in a commercial declares, “The power of Quaker is in everything we make.” Television, print, online (quakeroats.com/gohumansgo) and outdoor ads  along with promotions and events around the country  proclaim that the Quaker oat is a “super grain” that “gives you a little lift, physically and emotionally” and “makes you feel good knowing you’re doing something good for yourself.” It seems counterintuitive to accentuate the positive amid all the downbeat financial news. But Madison Avenue is typically a place called Hope. Besides, gloom-mongering could convince consumers to put off what little spending they still intend. “You could always look at the glass as half-full or half-empty,” Annie Young-Scrivner, chief marketing officer and vice president for sales at the Quaker foods and snacks division, said on Monday at an event in Times Square to introduce the campaign. “We look at it half-full,” she added, which suits “a very iconic brand” like Quaker.  As Quaker Oats cheers on the human race, Visa has a campaign that also plays up the word go, which carries the theme “More people go with Visa.” And the Hillshire Farm unit of Sara Lee is running a humorous campaign under the banner “Go meat!” Those go-go ads join a lengthening list of cockeyed marketers sponsoring campaigns carrying optimistic themes. They include Bank of America, with “Bank of opportunity”; Coca-Cola, with “Open happiness”; the Pepsi-Cola soft drink sold by PepsiCo, with ads in which the o’s in words like “hope” are replaced by a logo resembling a smiling face; and Western Union, with a one-word burst of positivity: “Yes!” “We did a great deal of research around the globe,” said Gail Galuppo, executive vice president and chief marketing officer at Western Union in Englewood, Colo., and determined that customers were still “working hard in pursuit of their dreams.” “In a world today where they hear a lot of ‘no’ and ‘maybe,’ ” she added, “we wanted to say ‘yes’ to them.” The Western Union campaign is by the Hong Kong office of Publicis Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe. The Quaker campaign, with a budget estimated at more than $100 million, is being created by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group. Another Omnicom agency, OMD, is handling the media part of the campaign. Edelman, part of Daniel J. Edelman Inc., is publicizing elements of the campaign like the Go Project, through which Quaker Oats will donate food to Share Our Strength, and Go Grants, $500 stipends from Quaker to consumers to start efforts to fight hunger in local communities. Many campaigns that are trying to put on a happy face during hard times are including charitable or philanthropic aspects to increase their feel-good appeal to feel-bad consumers.  The Quaker campaign is about “leveraging human energy to fuel your day,” Ms. Young-Scrivner said, “and also leveraging human energy to do more for others.” The development of the campaign began last summer. “Obviously, economic conditions are definitely a factor” in marketing decisions, Ms. Young-Scrivner said, but the premise of the campaign to “fuel yourself to be your very best” ought to resonate in a recession. A TV commercial and an accompanying print ad reflect that attitude, minus any presidents, by showing a man flying to work with a jetpack on his back powered by two packages of Old Fashioned Quaker Oats. A second ad compares Quaker Instant Oatmeal to a ramp that can send a child’s bicycle soaring into the air. A third ad, likening Quaker Chewy Granola Bars to a spring, urges shoppers to “put a little spring in your step.” The fourth ad depicts a section of the oatmeal package in the shape of a heart. “Take good care of your heart, and your heart will take good care of you,” the text reads. “Quaker Oatmeal has been helping lower cholesterol for 20 years.” The campaign represents the first work for Quaker Oats from Goodby, Silverstein since being selected last fall as the company’s lead creative agency. Goodby, Silverstein won the assignment from another Omnicom agency, Element 79 Partners. “Every once in a while as an advertising agency, you are presented with a brand that has great familiarity, great perceptions attached to it, but it’s out there in a latent phase,” said Jamie Barrett, partner and creative director at Goodby, Silverstein. The campaign offers “a focus and a mission for the products as a brand,” he added, which ought to increase product sales as it burnishes the image of the brand. The ads have a contemporary attitude, Mr. Barrett said, while at the same time acknowledging the heritage of Quaker Oats. “The Quaker Man has been an icon for more than a century,” he added, “so we wanted to make sure what we did was true to the brand, served up in a way that rang true and doesn’t take it to a place that’s not genuine.” The campaign began last week with so-called teaser ads, billboards and signs in a dozen large markets that showed only parts of the Quaker Man. The “reveal” came on Monday at the event in Times Square, along with material on the Quaker Oats Web site explaining the campaign. The jetpack TV commercial is scheduled to start next Monday, along with newspaper ads; outdoor ads bearing the “Go humans go” theme, appearing in 20 large markets; and ads on Web sites like health.com and instyle.com. Magazine ads are planned for later this month, as are activities involving bloggers. U.S. Widens Net on Pricing of Food Supplies for G.I.’sPublished: October 18, 2007WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  Federal agents are investigating whether several large food companies charged the government excessively high prices for supplies to American troops in Iraq and Kuwait, administration officials said Wednesday. Widening their previously disclosed inquiries into contract fraud and corruption in Kuwait and Iraq, investigators from the Justice and Defense Departments are examining deals that the Sara Lee Corporation, ConAgra Foods Inc. and other American companies made to supply the military, officials said. The inquiry centers on whether the companies overcharged the Army’s principal food supplier for the war zones, a Kuwait-based company called the Public Warehousing Company. Investigators are also looking into whether Public Warehousing improperly took payments from the food companies. Public Warehousing, which supplies enormous amounts of fruits, vegetables and meats for more than 160,000 troops in combat zones, said in a statement that it had done nothing wrong and was fully cooperating. But a Justice Department lawyer, Brian A. Mizoguchi, told a Federal Claims Court judge in Washington on June 12 that Public Warehousing’s business arrangements were the target of “a very large and active investigation into criminal fraud involving amounts in the hundreds of millions of dollars.” “It relates directly to the contracts,” Mr. Mizoguchi said, “because it relates to the pricing and costs under those contracts.” Public Warehousing, which is now called Agility Logistics, receives more than $1 billion a year to feed troops in Iraq and Kuwait. The investigation, which was reported Wednesday in The Wall Street Journal, is also focusing on Army officials who picked the food companies that are Public Warehousing’s suppliers. Procurement specialists said that once vendors like Public Warehousing received guidance from the Army Center of Excellence, Subsistence, at Fort Lee, Va., on what should be on the menu in chow halls, the vendors sought suppliers for that food. In some cases, the Army had designated specific companies to provide certain foods, like beef or chicken, which has drawn protests from rival companies. For example, Tyson Foods, the nation’s largest meat company, has complained to the Pentagon that some food companies have hired former military procurement officials to use their contacts to help win lucrative government contracts. Timothy L. Hale, a spokesman at Fort Lee, said the Army agency had not been notified that it was under investigation. He referred questions to the Justice Department. In a statement, Public Warehousing said its service had been “timely, reliable and cost-effective.” The company’s position is that what investigators are looking at as improper payments were actually discounts received for paying its suppliers ahead of schedule, a widely accepted practice in the food industry. In court papers, Public Warehousing cited an e-mail message in October 2006 from a military contracting officer telling the company that the practice of discounts was appropriate. Public Warehousing attributed its high prices partly to the costs associated with storing, handling and transporting supplies to multiple locations in a war zone. The company said more than 30 of its employees had been killed and 200 wounded in the war zones. Several food companies said they were cooperating with investigators. ConAgra Foods said it first received a request for information from the Pentagon in January. “ConAgra Foods has been assured by the Department of Defense, which is leading the investigation of Public Warehousing Company, that its role in this investigation is limited to that of a witness,” the company said. ConAgra has provided “relevant records and testimony to the government investigators.” ConAgra officials denied that they had overcharged. Officials for Sara Lee said they too had received a subpoena in January and had been assured that the company was not a target of the inquiry but a witness. Kenneth G. Trantowski, a spokesman for Quantum Foods, said the company had received a subpoena during the summer from the federal prosecutors related to an investigation of “food industry practices as it relates to the military,” but said the company was not a target of the investigation. Quantum Foods, based in the Chicago suburbs, has supplied meat, chicken and meals to the military since 2000, and has been shipping to Iraq since 2002. Tyson and some other major companies say they are being excluded from the lucrative war-zone market. Tyson sent a letter to the Defense Logistics Agency on April 3 outlining the company’s concerns about the way some food purchases by the military “appear to favor certain companies employing former military food service personnel,” Gary Mickelson, a company spokesman, said in an e-mail message. In the letter, Jenna R. Johnston, Tyson’s senior counsel and assistant secretary, requested a meeting to discuss what the company believed were unfair procurement practices. Specifically, she complained that some elements of the military were negotiating single-source, multiyear agreements with Tyson’s competitors worth hundreds of millions of dollars. She argued that it was inappropriate for the military to specify brand name merchandise for “commodity raw chicken pieces, French fries, ground beef, liquid eggs,” since they are typically served with no brand visible. Margot Williams contributed reporting from New York. Arriving, Goal by GoalPublished: September 9, 2007I GREW up in upstate New York with three siblings. When I was born, my two sisters were 7 and 9 years older; my brother was 12 years older. The three of them were fairly competitive growing up. Skip to next paragraph *JAMES NOLAN* Chief executive, Sara Lee Foodservice BIRTH DATE Nov. 6, 1955 BIRTHPLACE Troy, N.Y. FAVORITE PHRASE If you are going to lead, lead. If you are going to follow, follow. If you are not going to do either, get out of the way. When I was 5 years old, my brother took me to see a regatta on Onondaga Lake. There were a couple of thousand people lining the shore. He was very insistent that I see the end of the race. There were fewer than 50 people at the end. The participants were exhausted. The losers were exasperated. Instead of just seeing the race as an event, my brother also showed me what the outcome meant for the participants. My father died when I was 14  Jan. 13, 1970. His passing was unexpected and marked my entire childhood. I felt compelled to take care of my mother, and within a year and a half I had a job at Aunt Cookies Sub Shop in Geneseo, N.Y., after school and on weekends. I made the sandwiches and learned a lot about interacting with customers. The lessons still apply today. The shop is still there. I order the turkey on Italian bread with extra peppers when I visit. I left home to attend Ithaca College, intending to major in education and become a coach. I decided to go out for the basketball team. By the time I was a senior, I was co-captain. At that years banquet, the basketball coach highlighted my work ethic and leadership. The next day the provost who had been at the dinner called me into his office. I was nervous; I had never met him. He told me that he had been impressed and had a friend who was a recruiter for Procter & Gamble and who could set up an interview for me. It was 1977. I was married and had a baby and I was sending out résumés to be a teacher. I decided to take the interview. I met two recruiters in Ithaca at 6 a.m. They were two Cornell graduates who had been out to some fraternity the night before and stayed out a little too late. I got passed along to the next level. About one month later, I received a job offer for the food service division in Boston. I went door to door selling industrial shortening and oil. There was a clam shack that served fried food in Worcester, Mass., that was a heavy user of oil. If I got the account, it would open the door to other customers. Knowing the place was open only seasonally, I visited the owner twice a week at 6 a.m. the entire summer and landed the account. When he became a client, we went to a celebratory Yankees-Red Sox game in New York. He was a big Red Sox fan. He taught me an important lesson: Let the client know who you are and what you stand for. I went from there to become a national account manager at Pepsi-Cola. Over the years, Ive discussed business with my four kids. Three have business careers now. The youngest is a college senior, majoring in sales management. I used the same sense of structure and incentives with them that I did in managing a work force. I bought my oldest daughter her first car, an old Saab. It was totaled within a few months. I told her I would match whatever she saved to buy a replacement. As a separate incentive, I said that if she received a B or better average I would double the amount that we would pay. It was really no different than structuring an incentive program at work and setting consistent goals. She rode a bicycle, got rides from her mom and dad and her friends. It took her about a year to save for the car. She ended up buying a Jeep and was never in an accident with that car. She also had a few more years of driving experience, which helped us sleep at night. By December 2001 I had moved to the Pepsi bottler, Pepsi Americas. I received a call about an opening in the food service division of Sara Lee. It felt like coming back home. As told to Amy Zipkin. Sara Lee is based in Chicago. Globalization in Every LoafPublished: June 16, 2007DOWNERS GROVE, Ill.  In a glassed-off area in the headquarters of Sara Lee, a handful of specialists study computer screens and flat-screen televisions beaming the latest weather reports and commodity prices. They are sourcing ingredients from all over the world to make Sara Lee’s assortment of breads, deli meats and microwaveable desserts. Skip to next paragraph Illustration by The New York Times Multimedia Graphic A Multinational Loaf Peter Wynn Thompson for The New York Times It is our responsibility to make sure what we are feeding people is safe, said David L. Brown, Sara Lees vice president for procurement. The lowering of trade barriers more than a decade ago has pushed food companies to scour the globe for more exotic  or the cheapest  ingredients to compete in a more global marketplace, not unlike automakers shipping in parts from all over. But with America’s relatively permissible food-import rules and weak inspection regime, is the trend to assemble food from so many far-flung locations heightening the risks of contamination? “Once ingredients are incorporated into processed foods, it is hard to check whether they come from overseas or to verify if there are any unsafe contaminants in the products,” said Michael F. Jacobson, executive director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington lobby group. “This is increasing the chances that people will get unsafe food.” The concerns of Mr. Jacobson and some in Congress are being stoked by the recent scandal involving pet food contaminated with an industrial chemical called melamine and imported from China, which has resulted in thousands of pets being sickened or killed. Food industry executives say they understand the risks of foreign sourcing and are taking pains to mitigate them. “Ingredients from overseas are not the issue,” said Robert Earl, senior director of nutrition policy at the Grocery Manufacturers of America, a trade group that represents many of the largest food processors. “The problem comes from incorrect practices from manufacturers that happen to be in another country.” David L. Brown, Sara Lee’s vice president for procurement, said consumers should not be concerned. “We are going to do our homework,” he said, including vetting foreign factories and in some cases investing money to improve food-safety standards. “It is our responsibility to make sure what we are feeding people is safe. But the more variables you enter into, the more risk you have naturally. It is all about how you address those unknowns.” The controls in place to ensure that foreign-sourced ingredients are safe “are evolving as the world changes,” Mr. Brown said. Some people say they still have a long way to go. In the weeks since the pet food controversy broke, federal investigators have also discovered toxic toothpaste exported from China and melamine-laced ingredients for fish feed manufactured in Toledo, Ohio. The discoveries have prompted new calls by Congress to overhaul responsibility for America’s food-safety system, which is currently shared by the Food and Drug Administration, the Department of Agriculture and a grab bag of other agencies. Critics say the F.D.A., which bears the bulk of the food-safety load, is woefully underfinanced and understaffed, and they note that fewer than 1 percent of imported food shipments undergo laboratory analysis. The number of food inspectors has decreased in the last five years. The F.D.A. is exploring ways to use risk analysis to try to pinpoint food shipments that might pose hazards, The Wall Street Journal reported this week. Under the approach, countries and private companies might be required to provide the F.D.A. with more information about imported food. The rise in imported ingredients has been accompanied by an explosion in imported food generally: food imports more than doubled in the last decade, to $79.9 billion, according to the United States International Trade Commission. Consumers can only guess from reading most labels that individual food products today contain ingredients from a handful of continents. Despite having the world’s most expansive and efficient agricultural sector, America is hardly the only place where large food processors like Sara Lee, Kraft and General Mills have looked to acquire the dozens of ingredients that make up their microwaveable meals, processed cheeses, baked snack foods and breakfast cereals. What trade commission figures show is that ingredients are streaming in from more than 100 countries, including China, India, the Philippines and countries in sub-Saharan Africa. In some cases, consumer demand for more ethnic foods in the United States is pushing companies to import harder-to-find foods from exotic locales, but in other cases the phenomenon is simply a function of the way modern processed foods are assembled. The imported ingredients include caseins and caseinates (enzymes found in milk that are used as milk protein substitutes for pizza cheeses) and gums and resins that are used as binders to, for example, give chicken nuggets a certain consistency. The scope of the global food marketplace is evident on the Web site of the Institute of Food Technologists. There, for the last six years, the Food Technology Buyer’s Guide has offered places to buy ingredients from around the world. 1 2 Next Page » Andrew Martin contributed reporting. No Sex and No Models (What Kind of Bra Ad Is This?)Published: July 15, 2006Will bras sell without sexy ads? Victorias Secret and its lineup of curvaceous models with names like Gisele and Heidi may not think so. But Sara Lee Branded Apparel, the maker of Playtex, Bali and Hanes, is testing a new strategy: leave the supermodels out of the advertisements. Starting this month, the company will promote its Barely There brand with a national campaign that shows no slinky body parts and no stiletto heels. Instead, the campaign is part sales pitch, part public service announcement. It tries to illustrate the practical problems women encounter with their underwear, like bumps, ripples and the unintended transparency that the wrong bra can produce under clothing. The ads are meant to take the place of a gimlet-eyed girlfriend  someone who will matter-of-factly tell you that your strap is showing, or that a lacy bra has no place under a shirt made of thin fabric. It is a departure for Barely There, which in the past has subscribed to the standard formula of womens underwear advertising. It was pretty consistent with the market, with high-end fashion models, said Tolli Love, vice president for marketing at Barely There. But the new campaign, she said, is definitely from the female perspective. Men are attracted to that type of advertising, Ms. Love said of the previous campaign. I think theres a perception that with intimate apparel, sex sells, and then women, too, are unfairly grouped into that category. The Barely There print ads look like a before-and-after picture, with two bras side by side that illustrate a result of an ill-chosen bra. On the left is a bra that is bumpy or misshapen (labeled There). On the right, a bra with a monochromatic background (Barely There.) The There bras are adorned with objects that signify bumps, ridges and other bra-related problems. (The objects the Martin Agency of Richmond, Va., dreamed up include headlights, Jiffy Pop, pine cones and pointy pink drink umbrellas.) The ads will appear in the August issues of fashion and consumer magazines like Allure, Cosmopolitan, Essence, InStyle and Real Simple, and on billboards in Times Square and in Los Angeles. Barely There is hoping to occupy a vacant corner of underwear advertising: practicality, which is usually left out of both the ads and the product. After all, this is an industry that created the corset, a garment that could cinch a narrow waist, as Scarlett OHara famously demanded, down to 18 and a half inches. More recently, the industry invented the once-ubiquitous thong, a piece of underwear that many wearers say is every bit as uncomfortable as its appearance suggests. But lately, attention has been lavished on the fact that millions of hapless American women are wearing ill-fitting bras. (By some estimates, as many as 85 percent of the female population.) So more marketers are shying away from ads with over-the-top sexiness in favor of a more educational approach. There are indications that the industry is looking beyond sexy ads. Even Victorias Secret created an ad in 2004 that starred Bob Dylan (though he was in the company of several supermodels). And brands that are famous for their flesh quotient have experimented with more creative alternatives. Wonderbra, mostly known for in-your-face ads showing smiling models from the chest up and not much else, is one: the brand introduced a crop of ads in Britain last year that took an understated, sly approach, depicting a restaurant full of men staring straight ahead, at a woman who is not in the picture. Another Wonderbra ad that ran in France showed only a line of text reading ABRACADAbra atop nothing but white space. But for decades, selling lingerie without buxom models has been practically unthinkable. Maidenform first shocked consumers at the end of World War II with a scandalously revealing ad campaign, depicting women cavorting in a state of toplessness except for their Maidenform bras. Getting maximum publicity from underwear ads is best achieved with nearly naked models. In the early 90s, the unknown-at-the-time rapper Mark Wahlberg dropped his pants for a Calvin Klein ad in Times Square, turning himself into an international celebrity. The original Victorias Secret TV fashion show in 2001 garnered enormous ratings on ABC, followed by more than 900 complaints to the Federal Communications Commission from groups like the Concerned Women for America. Even the planners of the Barely There campaign defend that other, more aspirational type of ad, even if it is primarily done by men, said Rob Schapiro, the creative director and senior vice president of the Martin Agency. (Mr. Schapiro was the only male member of the creative team.) Victorias Secret has had success owning sexy, and I think theres a certain segment of the population that wants a sexier bra, Mr. Schapiro said. But, he added, we realized that a large segment of the population is concerned about how she looks in her bra while actually wearing clothing. More Articles in Business »Will bras sell without sexy ads? Hanes Revives a Successful Campaign From the 90'sPublished: February 24, 2005OR those who have been waiting for Hanes to revive "Just wait'll we get our Hanes on you," the wait is over - kinda sorta. In a campaign scheduled to begin on Monday, which is being billed as the largest in years for the Hanes apparel brand, the "Just wait'll" theme, so successful in the 1990's, returns with a bit of tailoring as "Look who we've got our Hanes on now." Also being revived is the idea of using a roster of celebrities to sell Hanes underwear, sleepwear, socks and other clothing, rather than the single-star approach the brand has recently taken in featuring Michael Jordan. Mr. Jordan remains, joined initially by Damon Wayans, Matthew Perry and Marisa Tomei, making the campaign perhaps the first to present a winner of an Academy Award for best supporting actress cavorting in her scanties. The yearlong television, print and online campaign, which has a budget estimated at more than $50 million, is being created by the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies. The campaign is an example of efforts by major marketers to capitalize on nostalgia for vintage slogans, themes, characters, commercials and the like. While such mining of the past is popular, the efforts for those brands - including Budweiser, Chicken of the Sea, Mr. Clean and Rheingold, as well as Hanes - also reflect a need to address today's consumers in a more contemporary fashion. In other words, even a campaign like "Just wait'll," which ran from 1992-99, could do with some updating. Brands "have to keep themselves fresh with consumers to be relevant," said Sidney Falken, who has the title of Hanes brand champion at Sara Lee Branded Apparel in Winston-Salem, N.C., a division of the Sara Lee Corporation. Because "consumers know this brand really well," Ms. Falken said, the idea of using celebrities they may not expect to see endorsing Hanes is meant to convey that the Hanes name can be found on apparel that is more stylish, colorful and comfortable than they may expect. In addition to the four stars who will appear in the TV commercials that will start on Monday, Hanes and Martin are considering additional celebrities to join them in print advertisements that are to begin in July. Selecting the stars has been "an exhaustive process," said Rob Schapiro, senior vice president and creative director at Martin, because of the need to find "people we liked, who have their own sense of style, who worked with the brand and who worked with our consumers." Mr. Wayans, in his commercials, is shown shaving his head, "which is something he does every day," Mr. Schapiro said, and kidding around in front of a bathroom mirror. Ms. Tomei is at home alone, dancing and trying on clothes. Mr. Jordan and Mr. Perry play pool together, trading shots and quips as if in scenes from a Hollywood buddy comedy. David Robertson, brand communications director for Hanes at the apparel division, said that because the target market is broad, primarily men and women ages 18 to 49, the commercials will run in a variety of programs, including "Dateline NBC," "E.R.," "Good Morning America," "Law & Order," "Saturday Night Live" and "Without a Trace." In the "Just wait'll" campaign, Hanes was one of the first major marketers to present several stars, rather than one person. The lineup in the 90's included, in addition to Mr. Jordan, then-familiar faces like Carol Alt, Boomer Esiason, Steve Largent, Joe Montana and Phylicia Rashad. Using an array of celebrities can help protect a company if one of its endorsers gets into trouble. For instance, while T-Mobile, part of Deutsche Telekom, may be embarrassed because personal information from the Sidekick hand-held communicator belonging to one of its stars, Paris Hilton, turned up on the Internet, she is only one of more than a dozen celebrities featured in Sidekick commercials, created by Publicis in the West in Seattle, part of the Publicis Worldwide division of the Publicis Groupe. (A spokesman for T-Mobile in Bellevue, Wash., Peter Dobrow, said yesterday that the Sidekick campaign "will run its course as is.") The campaign for Hanes, the largest Sara Lee brand, is scheduled to start two weeks after Sara Lee announced that it would spin off its branded-apparel division and other units in 12 to 18 months, to concentrate on operations like food, beverages and household products. The Sara Lee plans call for the spinoff, which will sell brands including Bali, Champion, Hanes, Just My Size, L'Eggs, Playtex and Wonderbra, to form a stand-alone, publicly traded company, said Peggy Carter, a spokeswoman at the apparel division, which would rank around 380th on the Fortune 500, based on 2003 revenue. The timing of the spinoff and the campaign are coincidental, she said.

Reorganizing at Sara Lee Includes a New ChiefPublished: February 11, 2005fter decades of being a diversified conglomerate, the Sara Lee Corporation has concluded that hot dogs and underwear do not belong under the same roof. In a broad reorganization, Sara Lee named a new chief executive and announced plans to divest four businesses that together account for 40 percent of the company's revenue. C. Steven McMillan, who also announced that he was stepping down as chief executive, said Sara Lee would spin off its $4.5 billion apparel business, its $1.1 billion European packaged meat division, American coffee brands like Hills Bros. and Chock full o' Nuts, and a direct-sales unit for cosmetics and household products. The apparel unit, consisting of well-known brands like Hanes, Champion and Playtex, is Sara Lee's largest business and big enough to be a Fortune 500 company on its own. The division is also responsible for making leg wear under a license with the Donna Karan Company. Mr. McMillan, who will step down as chief executive, said a public offering for the apparel business is the most likely outcome, but he left open the possibility of a sale to another company. "It's highly possible that someone will come in and say we want to buy it," Mr. McMillan said. "But they would have to pay a premium to cover the taxes that shareholders wouldn't incur from a public offering." Brenda C. Barnes, a former PepsiCo executive, will succeed Mr. McMillan, who will remain as chairman through October. Hired by Sara Lee last May to be the company's president and chief operating officer, Ms. Barnes becomes one of eight women to head a Fortune 500 company. She is on the board of The New York Times Company. The extensive divestments are part of Sara Lee's gradual evolution from a company with a diverse array of products to a streamlined food operation. Sara Lee, which was known as Consolidated Foods until 1985, has owned brands as diverse as Piggly Wiggly supermarkets, Electrolux vacuum cleaners and Drum tobacco. The company sold the Coach brand of leather goods four years ago and phased out dozens of its bakery brands over the last two years to better concentrate on its three strongest brands. Mr. McMillan said the company derived little benefit from having both a food business and an apparel unit. "When you're dealing with retailers like Wal-Mart, the people who deal with the food side and the apparel side are totally different," he said. "For a while this was a company that bought anything they thought they could make money in," said Eric J. Larson, an analyst at Piper Jaffray, who has been following Sara Lee since the mid-1980's. "This is the final step to get this company truly focused." After the planned sales and spinoffs, Sara Lee will be left with dozens of bakery, packaged meat and coffee brands that are sold in American supermarkets, as well as a food service division that supplies restaurants and institutions. All of these businesses, now scattered in several cities, will be centralized in Chicago. In Europe, Sara Lee will continue to sell bakery and beverage products, as well as household items like Sanex soaps and Kiwi shoe polish. In a Web conference with financial analysts yesterday, Ms. Barnes said these moves were part of an important effort to make Sara Lee more centralized and cost-efficient. The company's many units have been operating on different technology systems and in different offices. Mr. McMillan said, "In many ways, we were all off in our silos." Later this year, Sara Lee will hire a chief information officer and a chief procurement officer. The company also plans to spend the next two years establishing a companywide supply chain and financial software system from SAP. The chief procurement officer will be responsible for heading a centralized purchasing initiative designed to gain better prices from suppliers. In announcing Ms. Barnes as his successor, Mr. McMillan, 60, portrayed the change as part of a planned transition. But some analysts said his departure after only four years in the job suggested that Sara Lee's board was less than happy with his tenure. While Mr. McMillan consolidated some manufacturing operations and centralized the meat business, he was also responsible for several acquisitions considered failures by analysts. "He wasn't moving fast enough and in a bold enough manner," said Eric Katzman, an analyst at Deutsche Bank. Sara Lee said yesterday's moves would not affect the company's earnings expectations of $1.46 to $1.56 a share for 2005. Theo de Kool, the chief financial officer, said a smaller Sara Lee would be much more profitable. The company hopes that in five years it will have the same level of operating income as today, which translates to an annual 6.5 percent a year growth in profits. Sara Lee's stock was up 4.1 percent, to $23.92, in trading yesterday.

Campaign Offers Alternative to the Low-Carb CrazePublished: February 1, 2005READ, long under attack, is finally striking back. The goal of a campaign that begins today in two East Coast markets and online (grainpower.org) is to counteract the onslaughts against bread from diet books and regimens that denigrate carbohydrates. The campaign is sponsored by a new organization, the Grain Foods Foundation, with 90 members that include marketers from the baking and milling industries like Cargill, ConAgra, Flowers Industries, General Mills, Interstate Bakeries and Sara Lee, along with trade associations and suppliers. "We'd had enough," said Paul Abenante, president and chief executive of the American Bakers Association in Washington, a foundation member. "We need to stand up for ourselves. Doing nothing is not an option." The campaign - with the theme "Bread. It's essential" - is created by Mullen in Wenham, Mass., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which has been developing it for more than a year. The posters and billboards, to appear initially in New York and Washington, are in addition to campaigns from several companies for new bread and cereal products with whole-grain recipes. The campaign is the most recent voice to be raised in the increasingly cacophonous public debate over diet and health, which is intensifying as questions arise over the growing obesity among Americans, especially children. "The noise level is extraordinary," said Marion Nestle, a professor of nutrition at New York University. "I expect health claims from every food in the supermarket." The campaign also comes as the federal government readies a revised version of the "food pyramid" to reflect new dietary guidelines, issued Jan. 12, that call for measures like eating more whole grains. "To the extent that the campaign emphasizes the benefit of eating whole grains in bread, it's a public service," said Dean Ornish, president of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute in Sausalito, Calif., "because whole grains are actually beneficial." But "to the extent the campaign is promoting all breads," said Dr. Ornish, who is also a clinical professor of medicine at the University of California, San Francisco, "it will confuse people" because "eating too many simple carbohydrates, white flour, refined grains, may increase health risks like diabetes and obesity." While doctors and dieticians praise carbohydrates as energy sources, refined carbohydrates like white bread can lead to weight gain because they are not filling. Some ads promote whole grains, like one that declares, "Whole-grain foods help control hunger." Others promote high-fiber diets and the folic acid found in enriched grain foods. But other ads are more general, centered on grains or carbohydrates. One, for instance, says, "A balanced diet that includes grains helps to prevent cataracts." Another declares, "Your brain needs carbohydrates to function properly." And all the ads end the same way: "Bread is delicious. Filled with healthy grains. And makes life better. Bread. It's essential." Judi Adams, president of the foundation, based in Ridgeway, Colo., agreed that "it is very, very important we get people to eat more whole grains, no question." She also said that there were "a lot of whole-grain products out there now that didn't used to be out there" because "we know people are not eating enough whole grains." But "everyone has their own taste preference," Ms. Adams said, "and it's important to get enriched grain, too," like breads fortified with folic acid to reduce birth defects. Mr. Abenante said: "There's no magic bullet. The issue is eating sensibly, eating in a balanced way, exercising." The campaign is not intended to promote refined grains at the expense of whole grains, he added, because it showcases products like "variety breads, whole grains, whole wheat" as well as conventional breads. Michael Jacobson, executive director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest in Washington, a longtime critic of marketing by the processed-food industry, said the ads for whole grains were excellent because "those are the kinds of foods people should be eating more of." "But a general pitch for carbohydrates is painting with too broad a brush because it's trying to bring white bread under the good news umbrella," he said. "I fear the advertising will not be encouraging people to eat the best kind of grains." Mr. Jacobson also offered a wry assessment of the campaign's theme: "I didn't know bread was 'essential.' A billion people in China must be horribly deprived." Continued 1 | 2 | Next>>

Kiwi Shoe Polish Aims to Escape InvisibilityPublished: December 14, 2004AN an irreverent campaign help a venerable product named after a flightless bird fly off the shelves? That is the ambitious goal of the campaign now under way for Kiwi, the line of shoe care products that dates to 1906. Kiwi is sold in almost 180 countries by the Sara Lee Corporation, the packaged-goods giant that also markets brands like Ball Park, Champion, Jimmy Dean and Hanes. After several years of little or no marketing support for Kiwi, Sara Lee is running print advertisements in a variety of national magazines. The ads, created by the Richards Group in Dallas, use sassy humor to try to stimulate demand for the brand. With the Kiwi campaign, which carries the theme "Look Sharp," Sara Lee joins a growing list of companies - among them Brown-Forman, Coca-Cola, Colgate-Palmolive, PepsiCo and Unilever - that are increasing marketing budgets for aging or neglected brands. The Kiwi ads are printed in bright red, matching the color in the background of the brand's logo, and show a can of Kiwi black shoe paste under snappy headlines. The sardonic tone is reminiscent of campaigns for Cheez-It crackers ("Get your own box") and Dodge ("Grab life by the horns"). The ads intend to persuade consumers, mostly male, to use the Kiwi shoe polish they already have in their homes. That, of course, would lead to more purchases of Kiwi shoe polish, shoe paste and shoe sponges. The strategy is a familiar one for brands that, like Kiwi, dominate their product categories. Remember the longtime theme for Campbell's soup, "Reach for the Campbell's, it's right on your shelf"? Kiwi is the best-selling shoe care brand in the world and has about 65 percent of that market in the United States, Bob Clark, marketing director for shoe care at the Sara Lee household and body care division in Exton, Pa., estimated. But such familiarity breeds, if not contempt, then perhaps indifference, particularly in prosaic product categories like shoe care. That is especially true when it costs so much to buy commercial time and advertising space. Decades ago, there were campaigns galore for ordinary products like hair tonic, gravy, watch bands and - yes - shoe polish, like the jingle for Esquire Boot Polish that promised it "gives your shoes that looking-glass shine." (Esquire, by the way, was acquired by Sara Lee years ago and discontinued.) "Some people say it's a bygone product for a bygone era," said Rob VanGorden, a principal at Richards, citing the trend toward dressing more casually. But "Kiwi dominates the category, has positive associations and a rich heritage," he said. "Although you can find Kiwi in just about every pantry, people only buy Kiwi when they run out," he added. "The real issue is, how do we get them to run out of polish more often?" Mr. Clark said: "When we spoke to consumers, they said they knew all about taking care of their shoes but were not doing it as much as they used to, even though they're taking care of all other kinds of grooming like their hair. It was not that they don't want to do it, it's just not top of mind." The result was the print campaign, with a budget estimated at more than $2 million, which is appearing in 18 magazines with a predominantly or primarily male readership. The jocular approach is meant to slyly nudge men to consider what shape their shoes are in, through irreverent headlines like these: "The difference between 'Here's my number' and 'Here's my real number.' " "The distressed look only works for jeans." "Dull shoes counteract polished résumés." "Hey. A topical cream that really does make you more attractive." "Men, your shoes should be polished regularly. Also, your sleeve is not a napkin." "Raise your chance of dating a supermodel from 0 to 0.001!" "Unpolished shoes are the open fly of footwear." Richards undertook what Mr. VanGorden called a "state of the shoes" exploration, going to bookstores, coffee shops and workplaces, talking to people about their shoes. The research showed that "most men are embarrassed," he said, making remarks like "I was going to polish them tonight" and "Don't take my picture." "The benefits of polishing your shoes are well known," Mr. VanGorden said, noting that even light users of polish say that having shined shoes is good. "The objective is increasing usage frequency that drives purchase, which is pretty simple, but sometimes simple ideas are what are needed." Richards is creating the campaign for Sara Lee on a project basis. The Kiwi agency of record remains Grey Worldwide in New York, part of the Grey Global Group. The Kiwi brand executives called Richards, Mr. VanGorden recalled, after reading an article in the trade publication Brandweek about Chick-fil-A, a Richards client along with brands like Corona, Home Depot and Motel 6. Chick-fil-A, the fast-food chain, is "an under-$10 million client," Mr. VanGorden said, but the Kiwi executives said they thought the media spending was $50 million to $100 million, based on the ubiquity and popularity of the campaign, which presents cows asking consumers to "Save a cow, eat more chicken." The Kiwi campaign is running in magazines like Black Enterprise, Car and Driver, Cargo, Ebony, Esquire, Men's Fitness, National Geographic, Newsweek and Popular Science. There are also plans to create versions of the campaign for ad space in trains and on elevators as well as to put it up on a Web site. Kiwi and Richards would like "to reach men when they're in places they can notice the poor state of their shoes," Mr. VanGorden said, like bars, gyms, health clubs, restrooms and taxicabs.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Sara Lee Discloses Ad Support PlansPublished: February 23, 2004The Sara Lee Corporation in Chicago, seeking to stimulate growth after disappointing results, is categorizing the level of advertising and marketing support that its brands should receive.At a presentation to analysts last week, Lee A. Sara Lee Says 3 Employees Under Scrutiny on RebatesPublished: April 08, 2003The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that three of its sales representatives had signed off on inaccurate rebate amounts for U.S. Foodservice, whose accounting is under investigation by federal regulators and prosecutors.The sales representatives remain employees at Sara Lee but are not allowed to work on any customer- or sales-related business, the company said.''Their focus is the investigation,'' Julie Ketay, a spokeswoman at Sara Lee, said of the employees. ''Once the investigation is complete, we'll make a further decision.''In examining the promotional and rebate payments, officials at Sara Lee say they discovered a discrepancy between company records and the documents that its sales representatives confirmed last week with Deloitte & Touche, the auditors for U.S. Foodservice. Sara Lee is conducting an internal inquiry and is cooperating with the investigations into U.S. Foodservice and its parent, Royal Ahold of the Netherlands.Royal Ahold said in February that it had overstated earnings by $500 million for the last two years because of accounting problems connected to payments made to U.S. Foodservice. The problems involved the inflation of promotional payments from suppliers, falsely increasing the unit's profit.The three Sara Lee sales representatives, who were not identified, were contacted by senior executives at U.S. Foodservice and asked to verify promotional and rebate amounts and balances due for distributing Sara Lee products, officials at Sara Lee said.The employees independently verified the amounts payable with auditors and confirmed payment amounts that were higher than what Sara Lee owed U.S. Foodservice. Steven McMillan, Sara Lee's chairman, president and chief executive said. ''Sara Lee's accounting for our business with U.S. Foodservice is both accurate and appropriate.''

RESPONSIBLE PARTY: TERRI THOMPSON; Your Tag Isnt ShowingPublished: December 01, 2002THE T-shirt tag, that often irritating and scratchy ribbon that sometimes peeks out of shirts and flips up onto the wearers neck, is becoming oh so pass at Hanes.The company, which makes more than 35 million T-shirts a year, eliminated the tags in mens T-shirts in October.
