Low Prices Threaten Coffee Farmers' Livelihood, Report SaysPublished: September 19, 2002Global economic forces are crushing millions of coffee farmers around the world, the British charity Oxfam said in a report released today.In Latin America, Africa and Asia, farmers are paid roughly 24 cents a pound for their beans, which may be the lowest price in a century, the report said.Four multinational companies -- Kraft, Sara Lee, Procter & Gamble and NestlÃ© -- buy nearly half the world's coffee and sell it for an average of $3.60 a pound, the report said. People in New York, Paris and Tokyo may pay almost that much for a single cup.The value of coffee exports has fallen by $4 billion since 1997 as supplies glut a market that was once regulated and is now free. Farmers in places like Mexico, Nicaragua and Guatemala are penniless and starving while ''the coffee companies are laughing all the way to the bank,'' the report said.''Asking some of the poorest and most powerless people in the world to negotiate in an open market with some of the richest and most powerful results, unsurprisingly, in the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer,'' the Oxfam report said.Oxfam timed the release of its report to coincide with the opening of a five-day meeting of the International Coffee Organization, in London, on Thursday. The organization has a plan to cut the coffee glut by barring export of the lowest-quality beans.Oxfam will ask members of the group -- 40 major coffee importers and exporters -- to agree to destroy about 660 million pounds of the lowest-quality coffee sitting in the world's warehouses, a move that would cost about $100 million.An economic analysis conducted for the International Coffee Organization said destruction would raise prices paid to coffee-producing nations by roughly $750 million and, Oxfam suggested, perhaps save some lives among the rural growers.The four corporations cited by Oxfam each said, in varying ways, that as buyers they were well aware of the crisis among coffee growers. But Kraft says it is ''fundamentally opposed to any scheme that intervenes on price.'' Sara Lee says it is ''uneasy about price support.'' Procter & Gamble says it wants ''to help address the underlaying social and economic issues'' -- but not through the International Coffee Organization.NestlÃ©, alone among the four, says it supports a price-control scheme led by the coffee organization. ''NestlÃ© is against low prices as they are not only bad for farmers, but also bad for NestlÃ©'s business,'' the corporation said.Fair Trade coffee, the response of an international movement that helps businesses buy directly from rural coffee cooperatives, eliminating the corporate middleman and paying farmers double or more the market price, is a growing alternative. Fair Trade coffee now represents about 2 percent of the world market. In the United States, such coffee is sold at about 10,000 retail outlets; sales grew 36 percent last year.But without a worldwide plan to raise prices paid to farmers and give them new alternatives to old ways, Oxfam said, the livelihoods of millions are at risk.''The coffee market is failing,'' the report said. ''It is failing producers on small family farms for whom coffee used to make money. It is failing local exporters and entrepreneurs who are going to the wall in the face of fierce international competition. And it is failing governments that had encouraged coffee production to increase export earnings.''

Many Chiefs Are Retaining Extra Benefits In RetirementPublished: September 11, 2002Often described as a model for chief executives, John F. Welch Jr. appears to have also created the model employment contract.The contract that Mr. Welch signed in 1996 as chief executive of General Electric was full of benefits that continue to flow to him in retirement. It quickly became a template for other executives to use to negotiate their own contracts, people in the field of executive pay say.So, like Mr. Welch, many retired chief executives of large companies now enjoy retirement benefits like free lifetime use of a company office and secretary and frequent access to a company plane. The executives typically receive the benefits in exchange for serving as consultants to their companies, the companies say.For John H. Bryan, Sara Lee's former chief executive, the company has agreed to pay for a car and driver through 2008, office space through 2009 and two administrative assistants through 2011. Mr. Bryan, who retired as chief executive in 2000, has a consulting agreement with Sara Lee that runs through 2009.AOL Time Warner is paying Gerald M. Levin, its former chief, who is now an adviser to the company, $1 million a year and providing him with office space in or near AOL's Rockefeller Center corporate offices, according to a report by the Corporate Library, a corporate-governance watchdog group.And Hugh L. McColl Jr., who retired from Bank of America in April 2001, has the use of an office, administrative support and, for up to 150 hours a year, a company plane, according to Executive Compensation Advisory Services, a research company in Alexandria, Va.Some details of Mr. Welch's benefits became public last week in a divorce court filing by his wife, Jane, who is seeking additional money to maintain her standard of living. They include courtside seats at the United States Open, satellite TV at his four homes and the use of a G.E.-owned apartment on Central Park West, in addition to paying for laundry, wine, newspapers and other items associated with the apartment.Some investors and corporate-governance experts have criticized the benefits, calling them another sign that company boards too often choose the welfare of executives over that of shareholders. ''We decided to go for that market.''More than 60,000 loaves of the bread are now baked daily in Madrid and the Canary Islands and more than 20,000 in Paris, Tex.The process isn't as easy as it sounds. Then, the bread is whisked into a sterile ''decrusting room,'' where it is sliced and immediately double-wrapped. The discarded bread is used for bread crumbs and croutons or sold for animal feed.''Industrially speaking, it is very difficult to make the bread,'' Mr. LladÃ³ said. ''Peel off the crust and the bread becomes very sensitive to anything in the air.''The bread sells for $2.59 to $3.19 a loaf, depending on the market; regular IronKids Bread, is $1.79 to $2.29. Although the loaves' dimensions are the same, the crustless variety weighs only 16 ounces, compared with 20 for the regular version. Both have the same shelf life, about eight days.''Here in the United States, the crustless bread tested for staying softer longer than regular bread,'' said Matt Hall, a spokesman for Sara Lee in St. Louis. Bread crust, he said, seems to absorb moisture from the white part of the bread. In Spain, the bread is promoted as ''100 percent tender.''All that may explain why Mr. LladÃ³'s children recently changed their dining behavior. ''Now they eat more sandwiches, and they love to produce them themselves because they look nicer,'' he said. ''They were eating the crust before. But now they don't.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

LONGTIME CLIENTS ABANDON AUDITORPublished: March 16, 2002Longtime clients, the federal government and even some of its own foreign affiliates abandoned Arthur Andersen yesterday, a day after the accounting firm was indicted for destroying Enron documents.Several of the firm's most loyal clients, including the Sara Lee Corporation and Abbott Laboratories from around its hometown, Chicago, said the time had come to switch auditors. Private Sector; Fast Cars, Harleys and CheesecakePublished: July 15, 2001THE muscular and dapper chief executive of the Sara Lee Corporation, C. Steven McMillan, used to drive Formula 2000 race cars as a hobby. He also took to riding Harley-Davidson motorcycles to relax. Pleads Guilty In Meat CasePublished: June 23, 2001The Sara Lee Corporation, one of the nation's largest makers of hot dogs and supermarket deli meats, pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor charge that it had produced and distributed tainted meat that sickened scores of consumers and was linked to about 15 deaths.The company agreed to pay $4.4 million to settle civil and criminal charges brought by the United States attorney for Western Michigan after a 1998 nationwide recall of deli meats and hot dogs that were produced at the company's Bill Mar Foods plant in Zeeland, Mich.Sara Lee, which makes Ball Park and Hygrade hot dogs and Sara Lee Deli Meat, recalled about 15 million pounds of meat in December 1998 after the federal government determined that a rare strain of listeria bacteria in the company's hot dogs and cold cuts had probably sickened people in several states. INSIDE ART; Expanding Its Art, TooPublished: April 21, 2000As the Museum of Modern Art gears up for its $650 million expansion, it is concerning itself with more than bricks and mortar. The works include ''Torsione,'' a 1968 construction in cement, wood and leather by Giovanni Anselmo, and ''Mitragliatrice,'' (''Machine Gun'') from 1966, made from reworked automobile parts by Pino Pascali.''The Anselmo is a particularly iconic work,'' said Glenn D. REPORT ON EXECUTIVE PAY; J.C. Penney Bosses in Stock BindPublished: April 02, 2000MANAGEMENT experts and institutional investors constantly lobby American executives to own more stock in the companies they run. Unlike options -- which, at worst, are worth nothing -- ownership of actual shares brings a downside. When investors lose money, so do the people running the company.In a year when many old-economy stocks declined, that danger became real for top executives. Few lost as much as the bosses at J.C. Penney, the giant retailer, whose stock lost more than half its value during 1999.Most companies require chief executive to own stock worth three to five times their annual salary, said James A. Hatch, an executive vice president at the Compensation Resource Group, a pay consulting firm in New York. Penney is more aggressive. Its chief executive, James E. Oesterreicher, must own seven times his annual salary, according to the company's most recent proxy. The ratio declines for lower-level executives, down to one and a half times salary for store managers.In 1998, the most recent year's proxy available for Penney, Mr. Oesterreicher made $612,000. He did not own quite seven times that in early 1999, but he did hold about 80,000 shares, worth about $3 million at the time. (The shares had been worth about $4 million only a few months before.)Today, however, with J.C. Penney's stock trading at $14.875, 80,000 shares would be worth just $1.19 million. If Mr. Oesterreicher received no raise last year and still holds 80,000 shares today, he would have to buy an additional 200,000 to comply with the company's policy. Through a spokeswoman, he declined to comment.Many other chief executives find themselves in similar predicaments. Coca-Cola, Eastman Kodak, Sara Lee and Sears, Roebuck all have stock ownership policies, and all saw their price drop in 1999. To follow their own rules, executives there would have to do some serious value investing -- or persuade their boards to hand over thousands of free shares. DAVID LEONHARDT
